/* Use in water purification */ Colloidal silver disinfects but it doesn't does not 'purify'. Purification is the physical removal of impurities.

message: /* Operations */ Expanded this to include the complete quote from the charter concerning council membership. The previous abbreviated quote was misleading. See discussion.
/* History and applications */ Added reference to use in space of electrolytic colloidal silver.
Removed silver chloride and iodide. I don't believe these are common compounds in colloidal silver. More on the discussion page.
Reinserted 'Colloidal silver' prior to 'complexes'. The Pubmed reference clearly calls it 'Colloidal Silver' and we have agreed on the broader definition. You are playing word games.
Reintoduced reference with revised explanation and moved it to Applications.
Reintroduced reference with a modification to para
Reintroduced the reference. The opening para clearly includes ionic silver in the 'broader definition' of colloidal silver.
Added antimicrobial reference as explained on discussion page.
[[WP:UNDO|Undid]] revision 253896005 by [User talk:MastCell) How can it be 'reliable' if it uses 'ionic' silver. This abstract is too vague to use to support such a crucial claim.
[[WP:UNDO|Undid]] revision 253776777 by [[Vsmith|Vsmith]]) Most of this article is about the 'marketed' version of CS therefore the broader definition should stay.
[[WP:UNDO|Undid]] revision 253761731 by [/Arthur Rubin|Arthur Rubin]]\ The 'broader definition' as defined in the opening para includes ionic products.
[[WP:UNDO|Undid]] revision 253741197 by [[Special:Contributions/MastCell|MastCell]] The full source provides proof the active ingredient in colloidal silver is antimicrobial.
Added reference to the antimocrobial properties of the predominent form of silver in commercial colloidal silver.
/* History and Applications */ It's legal position on selling CS is the same in the US and Australia

/* History and Applications */ Corrected this. The previous phrasing implied all shops and websites were engaged in illegal marketing practices.
/* History and Applications */ Removed 'cure-all'. Its hardly NPOV even if it did appear in a Journal. And it was prescription medicine. Don't imply the doctors were quacks.
Added new section appropriate to this subjects Wikipedia category: Alternative medicine.
/* Reports in humans */Paul Karosan also added salt to the water - as he explained in the attached reference. Salt greatly increases conductivity and the silver concentration.

It's simply a list of medical journals not a personal opinion page. The alternative is that I list every journal individually as an reference.
